Apr 11

What the heck is going on in the brain?

Understand more about why someone with autism is overwhelmed in situations that don’t bother others

Remember when you were in high school?

Walking down the hallway between classes, alongside two of your best friends?
You were probably able to carry on some light conversation, and listen and respond appropriately. Friends often joke around, using sarcasm or humor to skirt around what they really mean. You could tell the difference without trying.
At the same time, you could to pay attention to other kids in the hallway, digging through their lockers or chatting about the upcoming football game.
They might briefly talk to you in passing — asking for today’s homework or to say hello.
Someone may have bumped into you accidentally-on-purpose. But you automatically knew it was friendly. You may have punched back lightly, smiling and saying, “Back off dude!”
You both knew it wasn’t a serious invitation to fight.
Seeing a teacher coming toward you, you naturally made a path for her, as it is instinctual to allow a person of authority a bit of space in a sea of adolescents.
Once you get to your locker, you start mentally rehearsing for your quiz next period, as you spin your combination lock. . .

While this represents a typical 5-minute school break between classes, the number of simultaneous processes taking place are impressive. You automatically know:

  • Who or what you should look at
  • Who you should focus your hearing on, while at the same time being aware of what others are saying
  • The difference between literal and figurative language
  • The difference between fun pushing around and real fighting
  • What you need to remember for later and what you can forget
  • Personal space conventions

The reason this requires no overt effort from you is because your brain naturally coordinates your thoughts and actions.

You don’t have to think about it.

This coordination depends on the millions of short- and long-range connections that stretch between areas of your brain, creating networks.

Someone with autism may have serious difficulty taking in this whole scene.

For them, focusing on so many things at once is difficult and may cause anxiety, especially when there are social elements involved.

WHY IS THIS?

The short answer is because the brains of people with autism are “wired” differently. They don’t have as many long-range connections, so their networks are less dense and well coordinated.

And being socially aware — like walking down a school hallway — is one skill that depends on a lot of separate brain areas working together.

This makes it really hard to filter what’s important from what’s not, and keep all the balls in the air at the same time. (Sounds stressful, huh?)

Another part of the connection story is that people with autism have MORE SHORT-RANGE CONNECTIONS in some parts of their brain. This helps explain why they are really, really good at some things, like visual-spatial tasks or computer programming.

← Think of these brain networks as smaller islands of activity

WHAT CAN YOU DO TO HELP?

RECOGNIZE THE SIGNS OF STRESS

Just like typically developing individuals, people with autism are not all alike and show signs of being overwhelmed differently. Behaviors can range from becoming very quiet (to the point of not being able to talk) to having a “melt down.”

IDENTIFY THE STRESSORS

What brings on the sense of being overwhelmed? During a relaxed time, discuss what aspects of a situation are triggers. Sounds? Cramped spaces? Too many people talking at once?

AVOID STRESSFUL SITUATIONS

Brainstorm and see if you can figure out a way to sidestep trigger situations. Instead of focussing on what they can’t do, focus on what they CAN do.

REDUCE SOURCES OF STRESS

Reducing even one source of stress can make a profound difference. For example, use earplugs or shut curtains to block out sources of auditory or visual stimulation.

ADD SOURCE OF COMFORT

A trusted friend or caretaker, an emotional support animal or using a comfort object can provide enough support to both get through stressful situations AND reach a higher level of functioning.
